path_1.title: Jurassic Park III (2001)
path_1.feeling: Solid dino thrills and brisk adventure scratched my creature-feature itch.

path_1.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_1.feeling: The toe-tapping music, offbeat humor, and heartfelt journey completely won me over.

path_1.title: Sing (2016)
path_1.feeling: Irresistible songs and warm, funny characters had me grinning the whole way.

path_1.title: Hugo (2011)
path_1.feeling: A tender, beautifully crafted family mystery that celebrates wonder and belonging.

path_1.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_1.feeling: Its quirky, spooky fun and playful imagination hit my sweet spot.

path_1.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Moving and mystical, though heavier than I prefer.

path_1.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_1.feeling: A heartfelt coming-of-age story with music and friendship that resonated.

path_1.title: Xanadu (1980)
path_1.feeling: The breezy music-and-romance vibe is charming, even if it’s lightweight.

path_1.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_1.feeling: Effective jumpy fun without being too intense for me.

path_1.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
path_1.feeling: Timeless songs and open-range romance swept me away.

path_1.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_1.feeling: Pitch-perfect suspense and voyeuristic intrigue kept me riveted.

path_1.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_1.feeling: Lush and thoughtful with a bittersweet romantic glow.

path_1.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_1.feeling: Stunning, soulful sci-fi that stirred both my eyes and heart.

path_1.title: Kiss Before Dying, A (1991)
path_1.feeling: A sleek, twisty thriller that satisfied my mystery cravings.

path_1.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_1.feeling: A moody, mythic western that hit the justice-and-redemption notes I love.

path_1.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_1.feeling: Rousing craftsmanship and camaraderie made the ride exhilarating.

path_1.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_1.feeling: Inspiring, adventurous, and full of awe for bold explorers.

path_1.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_1.feeling: Inventive, funny, and delightfully zippy with a clever mystery.

path_1.title: Kingpin (1996)
path_1.feeling: Goofy gags land enough to keep me chuckling, even if it’s hit-or-miss.

path_1.title: Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The (2012)
path_1.feeling: A cozy, spectacle-filled quest that’s fun if a bit long-winded.

path_1.title: Sure Thing, The (1985)
path_1.feeling: Cute and agreeable, but the rom-com road beats feel familiar.

path_1.title: Karate Kid, The (1984)
path_1.feeling: Earnest mentorship and uplifting training arcs gave me all the feels.

path_1.title: Fletch (1985)
path_1.feeling: Snappy wit and a light mystery made for an easy, fun time.

path_1.title: Radio Days (1987)
path_1.feeling: Warm, nostalgic storytelling with a lovely music-soaked glow.

path_1.title: Flashdance (1983)
path_1.feeling: The dance-fueled ambition and romance were spirited and satisfying.

path_1.title: Murder on the Orient Express (2017)
path_1.feeling: A classy whodunit vibe with enough intrigue to keep me engaged.

path_1.title: Goodfellas (1990)
path_1.feeling: Gripping, propulsive crime storytelling that pulled me right in.

path_1.title: Bull Durham (1988)
path_1.feeling: Smart, grown-up laughs and romance with a charming sports backdrop.

path_1.title: Mary Poppins Returns (2018)
path_1.feeling: Whimsical musical set pieces and gentle heart made me smile wide.

path_2.title: Jurassic Park III (2001)
path_2.feeling: Dino action delivered some thrills, but lacked the awe and heart I crave.

path_2.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_2.feeling: Toe-tapping odyssey with wit and warmth that had me grinning.

path_2.title: Sing (2016)
path_2.feeling: Pure family fun with infectious tunes and big-hearted characters.

path_2.title: Hugo (2011)
path_2.feeling: A tender love letter to movies with mystery and wonder.

path_2.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_2.feeling: Zany, spooky fun with playful imagination, if a bit scattershot.

path_2.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Moving in moments, but its heaviness and length muted my connection.

path_2.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, empathetic coming-of-age with friendship and music that resonated.

path_2.title: Xanadu (1980)
path_2.feeling: Campy roller-disco whimsy

path_2.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_2.feeling: A few effective jolts, though it feels like a safe retread.

path_2.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
path_2.feeling: Rousing songs and romance on the frontier—classic musical joy.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Masterful suspense and voyeuristic mystery that grips from start to finish.

path_2.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_2.feeling: Lush, contemplative romance with moments of magic, but it meanders.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Stunning, soulful sci-fi that mesmerized me with scale and emotion.

path_2.title: Kiss Before Dying, A (1991)
path_2.feeling: Slick and twisty, but lacks the depth of top-tier thrillers.

path_2.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_2.feeling: Mythic, measured Western justice that hit my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_2.feeling: Crowd-pleasing craft and camaraderie with exhilarating race-day stakes.

path_2.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_2.feeling: Inspiring, adventurous space history with camaraderie and awe that I love.

path_2.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_2.feeling: Inventive, zippy noir-toon blend bursting with humor and heart.

path_2.title: Kingpin (1996)
path_2.feeling: Some big laughs, but the crudeness blunts the charm.

path_2.title: Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The (2012)
path_2.feeling: A cozy, sprawling quest with charm, if a bit overlong.

path_2.title: Sure Thing, The (1985)
path_2.feeling: Cute opposites-attract road romance with light laughs—pleasant, not special.

path_2.title: Karate Kid, The (1984)
path_2.feeling: Classic underdog heart with mentor wisdom that totally works on me.

path_2.title: Fletch (1985)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, witty sleuthing that keeps the jokes and clues coming.

path_2.title: Radio Days (1987)

path_2.title: Flashdance (1983)
path_2.feeling: Stylized dance dreams and romance

path_2.feeling: Propulsive, engrossing crime saga with electric energy and unforgettable craft.

path_2.title: Bull Durham (1988)

path_2.title: Mary Poppins Returns (2018)

path_3.title: Jurassic Park III (2001)

path_3.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_3.feeling: Toe-tapping, clever, and warmly offbeat road-song.

path_3.title: Sing (2016)
path_3.feeling: Charmed by its big-hearted optimism and catchy tunes.

path_3.title: Hugo (2011)
path_3.feeling: Enchanted by its love of movies and tender sense of wonder.

path_3.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_3.feeling: Delightfully weird and witty with a mischievous streak.

path_3.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_3.feeling: Moving and mystical, if a bit heavy-handed and long.

path_3.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_3.feeling: Tender, empathetic, and bittersweet in all the right ways.

path_3.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_3.feeling: Efficiently spooky but missing the magic and dread that linger.

path_3.feeling: Perfectly taut and intoxicatingly voyeuristic.

path_3.feeling: Elegant and wistful, though a touch languid.

path_5.title: Jurassic Park III (2001)
path_5.feeling: Lean, peril-driven dinosaur mayhem scratches my survival-adventure itch without the wonder of the original.

path_5.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_5.feeling: A tuneful, rambling folk odyssey with sly humor and heart hits my sweet spot for Americana capers.

path_5.title: Sing (2016)
path_5.feeling: Joyful, music-first ensemble energy and gentle laughs make for a crowd-pleasing family watch.

path_5.title: Hugo (2011)
path_5.feeling: A tender mystery wrapped in clockwork wonder and film history beautifully feeds my love of awe and heart.

path_5.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_5.feeling: Macabre whimsy and anarchic gags are fun, even if the chaos occasionally outweighs the heart for me.

path_5.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: A compassionate, supernatural death-row tale moves me, even if it feels a bit overlong.

path_5.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Earnest coming-of-age aches and small joys resonate, if a touch teen-tidy for my taste.

path_5.title: Xanadu (1980)
path_5.feeling: Candy-colored tunes and rollerskating fantasy are charmingly goofy comfort rather than top-tier for me.

path_5.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_5.feeling: Familiar haunted-house jolts deliver some fun, though it never fully escapes the shadow of better versions.

path_5.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
path_5.feeling: Rousing songs, romance, and frontier spirit sweep me up completely.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: A taut, voyeuristic puzzle that perfectly marries suspense, wit, and character—catnip for my mystery side.

path_5.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_5.feeling: Lush, romantic fantasy with an eerie twist intrigues me, even if it lingers longer than it needs to.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Immersive world-building and soulful sci-fi mystery hypnotize me from start to finish.

path_5.title: Kiss Before Dying, A (1991)
path_5.feeling: Sleek 90s noir vibes and a chilling social climber plot scratch my thriller itch.

path_5.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_5.feeling: Lone-rider justice and moral hush on the frontier press all my Western buttons.

path_5.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_5.feeling: Craft, camaraderie, and high-octane stakes rev my love of underdog, history-tinged dramas.

path_5.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_5.feeling: Big-canvas heroics and human grit in the space race fill me with old-school awe.

path_5.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_5.feeling: A zippy noir caper with dazzling toon-human interplay hits my animation and mystery sweet spots.

path_5.title: Kingpin (1996)
path_5.feeling: Raunchy gutterball gags land enough laughs for me, even if the mean streak dulls the charm.

path_5.title: Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Cozy adventure and grand fantasy world-building delight me despite episodic bloat.

path_5.title: Sure Thing, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Snappy opposites-attract banter charms, though the 80s rom-com beats feel familiar.

path_5.title: Karate Kid, The (1984)
path_5.feeling: A heartfelt mentor-student bond and resilient spirit make this an uplifting, feel-good story that lands for me.

path_5.title: Fletch (1985)
path_5.feeling: Wry disguises and breezy mystery antics make for a witty, satisfying caper.

path_5.title: Radio Days (1987)
path_5.feeling: Warm, nostalgic vignettes about the magic of radio gently glow with humor and heart.

path_5.title: Flashdance (1983)
path_5.feeling: Style, soundtrack, and grit carry the day even if the romance threads feel thin.

path_5.title: Murder on the Orient Express (2017)
path_5.feeling: Glossy ensemble whodunit pleasures me with classic puzzle mechanics, even if the polish softens the bite.

path_5.title: Goodfellas (1990)
path_5.feeling: Propulsive, intoxicating rise-and-fall crime storytelling grips me start to finish.

path_5.title: Bull Durham (1988)
path_5.feeling: Easygoing clubhouse wit and mature romance make this sports charmer go down smooth.

path_5.title: Mary Poppins Returns (2018)
path_5.feeling: Whimsical set-pieces and earnest nostalgia deliver a delightful family uplift.

path_5.title: Jurassic Park III (2001)
path_5.feeling: Lean dino-chase thrills scratch my creature-feature itch even if it lacks the awe I crave.

path_5.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_5.feeling: Dusty road-trip caper with toe-tapping tunes and mythic whimsy hits my Americana sweet spot.

path_5.title: Sing (2016)
path_5.feeling: A buoyant, big-hearted jukebox menagerie that leaves me grinning and misty-eyed.

path_5.title: Hugo (2011)
path_5.feeling: Clockwork wonder, found family, and love of cinema speak directly to my sense of awe.

path_5.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_5.feeling: Macabre whimsy and manic gags amuse me, even if it’s more goofy than heartfelt.

path_5.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Earnest and moving in stretches, though the supernatural sentimentality feels a bit heavy for me.

path_5.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Tender, music-soaked coming-of-age about friendship and healing is exactly my thing.

path_5.title: Xanadu (1980)
path_5.feeling: Glittery roller-fantasy fluff charms me in spots but mostly as breezy, kitschy comfort.

path_5.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_5.feeling: Polished, jumpy haunted-house fun that entertains without truly chilling me.

path_5.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
path_5.feeling: Golden-age tunes, wide-open skies, and courtship stakes sweep me away every time.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Perfectly wound suspense and neighborly mystery—my ideal old-school thriller.

path_5.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_5.feeling: Moody, romantic fable with Death has moments I savor despite its languid sprawl.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Grand, soulful sci‑fi with haunting atmosphere and human ache—utterly absorbing.

path_5.title: Kiss Before Dying, A (1991)
path_5.feeling: Silky 90s noir vibes and deadly ambition make for satisfying, twisty intrigue.

path_5.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_5.feeling: Somber, mythic western justice delivered with the quiet gravitas I love.

path_5.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_5.feeling: Craft, camaraderie, and high-octane history rev me up in all the right ways.

path_5.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_5.feeling: Heroic, humorous, and awe-struck space-age saga that feeds my love of history.

path_5.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_5.feeling: Zany noir mash-up with heart and ingenuity is pure movie-magic fun.

path_5.title: Kingpin (1996)
path_5.feeling: Crude bowling shenanigans land some laughs but the raunch keeps me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Comforting, scenic quest vibes I enjoy even if it meanders.

path_5.title: Sure Thing, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Road-trip sparring turns sweet, delivering cozy romance with just enough spark.

path_5.title: Karate Kid, The (1984)
path_5.feeling: Mentorship, resilience, and triumph make for the kind of uplifting family drama I treasure.

path_5.title: Fletch (1985)
path_5.feeling: Wry, disguise-happy sleuthing scratches my cozy mystery-comedy itch.

path_5.title: Radio Days (1987)
path_5.feeling: Warm, nostalgic snapshots of bygone radio life play like a gentle, charming reverie.

path_5.title: Flashdance (1983)
path_5.feeling: Blue-collar dreams and catchy dance beats make for an earnest, feel-good rise.

path_5.title: Murder on the Orient Express (2017)
path_5.feeling: Plush, old-fashioned whodunit comfort—elegant, if a touch restrained.

path_5.title: Goodfellas (1990)
path_5.feeling: Propulsive, character-rich crime saga that grips me even as the brutality stings.

path_5.title: Bull Durham (1988)
path_5.feeling: Baseball lore, witty romance, and low-key wisdom make an easy, winning hang.

path_5.title: Mary Poppins Returns (2018)
path_5.feeling: Old-fashioned, colorful musical comfort that rekindles childlike wonder.

path_5.title: Jurassic Park III (2001)
path_5.feeling: Lean dino-peril and survival stakes scratch my adventure itch, even if it feels more thrill ride than wonder.

path_5.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_5.feeling: A tuneful, rambling odyssey with a relentless pursuit hits my sweet spot for witty, music-laced adventures.

path_5.title: Sing (2016)
path_5.feeling: A warm, funny, music-filled underdog showcase gives me exactly the family uplift I love.

path_5.title: Hugo (2011)
path_5.feeling: An orphan’s mystery and clockwork wonder in old Paris beautifully blend adventure and heartfelt belonging for me.

path_5.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_5.feeling: Macabre silliness and house-haunting hijinks amuse me with lively fantasy energy.

path_5.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Moving prison-set morality with a supernatural touch works for me, though the sentiment runs a bit heavy.

path_5.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Tender, empathetic coming-of-age about friendship and healing is exactly my kind of intimate drama.

path_5.title: Xanadu (1980)
path_5.feeling: Featherweight roller-disco fantasy charms in spots but feels too airy for me.

path_5.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_5.feeling: Family-in-peril hauntings deliver familiar chills I enjoy more for mood than deep scares.

path_5.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
path_5.feeling: Golden-age musical sweep, romance, and frontier warmth hit all my Western-musical buttons.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Perfectly calibrated suspense and neighborly mystery are everything I crave in classic thrillers.

path_5.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_5.feeling: Lush, dreamy romance with a supernatural twist engages me even if it lingers a bit.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Atmospheric, soulful sci-fi with big feelings and mystery utterly captivates me.

path_5.title: Kiss Before Dying, A (1991)
path_5.feeling: Wealth, secrets, and staged tragedy make for the kind of twisty 90s crime thriller I enjoy.

path_5.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_5.feeling: My sweet spot: a principled drifter bringing justice to a threatened frontier community.

path_5.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_5.feeling: Human drive, craft, and history-fueled competition rev me up in all the right ways.

path_5.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_5.feeling: Heroic, history-rich space-race storytelling fills me with awe and admiration.

path_5.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_5.feeling: Zippy noir hijinks with toons and a hard-luck detective delight my animation-crime sweet spot.

path_5.title: Kingpin (1996)
path_5.feeling: Broad, raunchy sports gags land inconsistently for me, though the underdog arc is fun.

path_5.title: Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Cozy, questing fantasy and camaraderie satisfy my adventure itch with plenty of wonder.

path_5.title: Sure Thing, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Road-trip bickering-to-bonding romance is cute and breezy, if a bit lightweight for me.

path_5.title: Karate Kid, The (1984)
path_5.feeling: Classic mentor-student uplift and heartfelt perseverance hit my family-drama sweet spot.

path_5.title: Fletch (1985)
path_5.feeling: Wisecracking sleuthing and light disguise-driven intrigue fit my taste for witty, cozy crime.

path_5.title: Radio Days (1987)
path_5.feeling: Warm, nostalgic vignettes about childhood and storytelling give me a gentle, satisfying glow.

path_5.title: Flashdance (1983)
path_5.feeling: Dream-chasing romance with musical drive works on me even if it’s more style than depth.

path_5.title: Murder on the Orient Express (2017)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, enclosed-carriage whodunit comforts me with classic clue-box pleasures.

path_5.title: Goodfellas (1990)
path_5.feeling: Vivid, propulsive rise-and-fall crime storytelling grips me with character and momentum.

path_5.title: Bull Durham (1988)
path_5.feeling: Smart, flirty baseball banter and grown-up romance make for warmly engaging comedy.

path_5.title: Mary Poppins Returns (2018)
path_5.feeling: Musical whimsy, family healing, and gentle magic deliver exactly the cozy uplift I love.

path_5.feeling: Lean, dino-run thrills scratch my creature-feature itch even if the stakes feel smaller.

path_5.title: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
path_5.feeling: Homespun odyssey, toe-tapping tunes, and sly humor hit my warm Americana sweet spot.

path_5.title: Sing (2016)
path_5.feeling: A joyful, kid-friendly underdog revue with big-hearted music keeps me grinning.

path_5.title: Hugo (2011)
path_5.feeling: A tender mystery and a love letter to moviemaking give me that wonder-and-heart mix I crave.

path_5.title: Beetlejuice (1988)
path_5.feeling: Macabre whimsy and house-haunting hijinks amuse me with just the right spooky-silly tone.

path_5.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Compassionate death-row fable moves me, though the sentiment runs a touch heavy for my taste.

path_5.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, empathetic coming-of-age with found-family warmth lands right in my wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Xanadu (1980)
path_5.feeling: Glitzy, airy fantasy-romance charms in spots, though the campy sheen keeps me at arm's length.

path_5.title: Poltergeist (2015)
path_5.feeling: A serviceable suburban-haunt remake that delivers familiar chills more than lasting dread.

path_5.title: Oklahoma! (1955)
path_5.feeling: Rousing songs, romance, and frontier spirit press all my classic-musical Western buttons.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Taut, playful voyeuristic suspense is pure old-school mystery bliss for me.

path_5.title: Meet Joe Black (1998)
path_5.feeling: Languid, high-concept romance has moments of tenderness that I like without fully sweeping me away.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Haunting, soulful sci-fi with grandeur and heart - exactly my kind of immersive future dream.

path_5.title: Kiss Before Dying, A (1991)
path_5.feeling: Silky, murderous ambition and a twin-driven puzzle satisfy my 90s thriller cravings.

path_5.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_5.feeling: Mythic, morally steady Western justice delivered with the quiet power I love.

path_5.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_5.feeling: Craft, camaraderie, and white-knuckle racing deliver the rousing, human-scale spectacle I savor.

path_5.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_5.feeling: Heroic grit and historical awe make this space-race chronicle deeply satisfying to me.

path_5.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_5.feeling: Inventive toon-noir, brisk mystery beats, and heartfelt fun are right up my alley.

path_5.title: Kingpin (1996)
path_5.feeling: Go-for-broke raunch and a mean streak bring laughs in parts but are not my comedy sweet spot.

path_5.title: Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The (2012)
path_5.feeling: A cozy, old-school quest with creature comforts and camaraderie fits my family-fantasy mood.

path_5.title: Sure Thing, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Cute road-trip opposites attract with enough charm, even if it is predictably featherlight.

path_5.title: Karate Kid, The (1984)
path_5.feeling: Heartfelt mentorship, underdog grit, and a big, earned payoff make for uplifting comfort.

path_5.title: Fletch (1985)
path_5.feeling: Snappy disguises and breezy sleuthing scratch my itch for light, witty mystery capers.

path_5.title: Radio Days (1987)
path_5.feeling: Warm, nostalgic vignettes about family and the magic of radio suit my gentle, memory-lane taste.

path_5.title: Flashdance (1983)
path_5.feeling: Aspirational dance romance and neon emotion work on me, even if it is melodramatic.

path_5.title: Murder on the Orient Express (2017)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, cozy whodunit pleasures with a beloved sleuth scratch my classic-mystery itch.

path_5.title: Goodfellas (1990)
path_5.feeling: Propulsive, lived-in crime saga grips me even as its brutality keeps me a half step back.

path_5.title: Bull Durham (1988)
path_5.feeling: Smart, grown-up sports romance with crackling banter hits that amiable, bittersweet groove I like.

path_5.title: Mary Poppins Returns (2018)
path_5.feeling: Whimsical musical escapades and gentle nostalgia deliver exactly the family comfort I enjoy.
